content.title: Lymphovenous Anastomosis (LVA)
content.definition: A microsurgical procedure connecting lymphatic vessels directly to nearby venules to bypass obstructed lymphatic pathways, allowing lymph fluid drainage into the venous system for treatment of lymphedema.

mechanism.physiology: Creates alternative drainage pathway for accumulated lymph fluid
mechanism.pressure_gradient: Lymphatic pressure exceeds venular pressure, driving flow
mechanism.functional_result: Reduction in limb volume and symptom improvement

ideal_candidates: Preserved functional lymphatics on ICG lymphography
No venous insufficiency in recipient vein

staging_importance.early_disease: Linear pattern on ICG - best outcomes
staging_importance.advanced_disease: Stardust pattern - poor outcomes for LVA alone

absolute: Active malignancy with lymph node involvement
relative: Absence of functional lymphatics on imaging

preoperative_mapping.planning: Identify patent lymphatic channels near superficial veins

surgical_approach.incision: Small (2-3 cm) incisions at mapped sites

compression.long_term: Continue compression garments (may reduce over time)

outcomes.compression_reduction: Many patients can reduce or discontinue compression

comparison_with_vlnt.combination: LVA and VLNT can be combined for advanced cases

codes.cpt: 38999 | Unlisted procedure, hemic or lymphatic system

clinical_pearls: LVA = physiologic procedure for early-stage lymphedema
ICG lymphography essential for patient selection and surgical planning
Linear pattern on ICG = best candidates for LVA
learning_objectives: Know staging and patient selection criteria
Describe ICG lymphography patterns and their significance
Compare LVA with VLNT for lymphedema treatment
board_review_points: Best for early-stage lymphedema (ISL Stage I-II)
